The new laboratory for Plant Physiology, a photograph of which we
publish on this page, is now completed. It is situated, with the adjacent
botanical gardens, just north of the Wyman mansion and west of the Carroll
mansion (Country School). It is directly behind the site of the proposed chapel.
It will be used by the graduate students of botany, under the direction of
Associate Professor Duncan Johnson. The well-equipped greenhouse which
adjoins it, is to be used for the cultivation of delicate plants. About 300
species are now set out and growing.
As the photograph indicates, the building is small, but it is of attractive
design, which will not jar with the magnificent structures which will in time
surround it.

HIS issue is just going to press when the news conies of Dr. Gilman's
sudden death. We can add nothing here to what will be said in the
• daily journals about his life. None can better appreciate his greatness, however, than those who are connected with the institution
••
whose success is the crowning achievement of his life.
'Act
But there is another, more personal side to the loss, which is
felt by all who are members of the University. Very few of the
present undergraduate body were personally acquainted with him,
• but we have the traditions of past years to shows us how much he
will be mourned by hundreds of Hopkins men all over the world.

NCE more the University has opened its doors to its students, and
college activities have begun with a vim. In this first issue of the
NEWS-LETTER the Board of Editors takes the opportunity to welcome
all the old students back as well as the Freshmen. It is not necessary to give another account of the policy of the paper, for this was
printed in one of the issues of last spring.
However, one change will be made, and that is to publish instead of a story in each number, an article written by one of the
faculty on whatever subject the author may select. For the first of
this series of leading articles we are greatly indebted to Dr. French,
who has written thoughtfully upon a very vital question, in which the undergraduates
especially will be interested.
We expect to have many other articles which will be just as important and delightful
to read. These articles if nothing more should make the students take a renewed interest in
the NEWS-LETTER. We shall also have a new cover design for each issue. These designs
will be the product of the students, and we shall be glad to receive for the approval of the
Board original pictures from all who draw. These will make the paper as attractive on the
outside as it will be on the inside.

Mr. J. Purdon Wright, who put the NEWS-LETTER on its present good financial basis,
has resigned, greatly to the regret of the board. We take pleasure in announcing the election
of Mr. H. P. Makel to succeed Mr. Wright as Business Manager.

A friend of the University has presented to it a collection of coins formed between 1850
and 1880 by the Marquis de Molius, a Spanish diplomatist, who served as Ambassador in
Paris and London. After his death it passed into the hands of Don Antonio Vives, the wellknown collector and numismatist of Madrid, from whom it was recently purchased. The
collection comprises more than 3,000 specimens, and includes coins of the Roman Republic,
(gold, silver and copper), of the Roman Emperors, (gold, 44, silver and copper), and 837
coins of the Iberian and Roman-Spanish cities and colonies issued prior to the reign of Caligula.
In this series of early Spanish coins lies the chief value of the collection, many of the known
issues represented being excessively rare, and several specimens in this collection being, so far
as is known, unique. Many years would be required to form another such Spanish collection,
and it would be most difficult to secure so many well-preserved specimens. The main interest
of this primitive Spanish coinage lies in the fact that it represents early Iberian art, and that it
furnishes the best original material for the solution of the many problems connected with the
Iberian language and Iberian epigraphy.
Don Antonio Vives, the last owner of the collection, by whom it was, to some extent,
enlarged, is author of the standard work on the coinage of the Spanish Moors, "Monedas de
las Dinastias Arabigo-Espanolas," Madrid, 1893. He formed the collection of Hispano_
Moorish coins now in the National Archological Museum at Madrid, which the Spanish
Government bought from him for 110,000 pesetas, and he owns the best private collection of
primitive Iberian bronzes, to which reference is made in many publications on this subject.
The following gifts have also been received recently for the department of Botany:
From the Park Commissioners of Baltimore, through Superintendent Manning, cuttings
of 50 species of exotic plants and 10 young plants; from Mrs. Augustus Hoen, of Baltimore, a
splendid specimen of Cycas revoluta and a fine clump of Strelitzia regince; from Professor H. S.
Collard, of Iowa College, formerly a Johnston Scholar of the University, a 1,000-gram chemical
balance.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

4

UPPER CLASSMEN AND LOWER.
BY JOHN C. FRENCH.

Being an upper-classman at Hopkins may,
perhaps, be regarded as a greater honor now
than in former years. The present seniors,
tho themselves completing a three-year course,
are as a class the last who will do so. From
now on seniors, being separated from freshmen by a greater interval, may justly demand
the greater respect from them, and in the
traditional enmity between sophomores and
freshmen, never having been the rivals of
either, they may now hold an unembarrassed
neutrality. Advice to new students as to
their part in college life has never been
scanty; they get kindly, wholesome words
from the Dean at matriculation, exhortations
from the captains of teams and clubs at the
opening reception, and fatherly counsel in
private from their advisers. Of such official
patronizing they have perhaps enough. The
time is opportune, however, to ask that upperclassmen shall take stock of their opportunities
and look their responsibilities in the face.
Those alumni who are concerned that
student life at Hopkins shall be enriched
with worthy traditions—and no others—look
to the upper-classmen to inaugurate and maintain them. Tho speaking as one having no
authority, I venture to say that both faculty
and alumni would give their moral support to
a greater dominance over college customs by
seniors. Let me hazard a few suggestions as
to what they would have seniors do.
Without question, the alumni would have
seniors put away childish things. Otherwise
they can serve no useful purpose as arbiters of
college affairs. A certain regrettable incident
of last year's student frivolity was all the
more regrettable because the disturbance—itself without precedent or excuse—was incited
and abetted by seniors.
Again, they would have seniors free themselves from all manner of partiality. As between freshmen and sophomores, they must be
capable of a judicial attitude. Students expect, and rightly, that such members of the
faculty as belong to fraternities having chapters here shall not carry the least memory of
their affiliations into the class room. An
equal impartiality should be possible to seniors.
The censor of college customs must wield a
spear that knows no brother.

If there is to be hazing—and I beg leave to
evade altogether the question whether there
should be—we should welcome some guarantee
that it wiil not be carried beyond the limits of
good-natured buffoonery. Is it not possible
to establish a tradition that no hazing whatever shall go on without the presence of a
Senior whose veto would be instantly respected? A referee is thought necessary when
the parties to a sport are evenly matched.
How much more necessary when one of them
is overborne by numbers and is expected for
the sake of future college spirit to carry away
no rancor in his heart! . I believe there has
been no brutal hazing at Johns Hopkins; yet
there have been freshmen, disposed to take
their hazing impersonally and as a sort of
initiation to Hopkins life, who have carried
on in bitterness the conviction that in their
case the limits of reasonable exaction had
been over-stepped. It is to prevent this, as
well as the possibility, remote as it is here,
perhaps, of physical injury thru some sophomore's excessive zeal, that I would have no
hazing except under rigid senior control.
Where there are several fraternities and
none too many students, rivalry becomes
keen and abuses are likely to creep in. It is
no secret that at Hopkins some regulation of
inter-fraternity competition is needed. To the
upper-classmen, again, we look for the inauguration of reforms. This may not be a matter
for legislation by the senior class-meeting, but
a senior pan-hellenic conference might reach
conclusions to which the weight of their influence would secure acquiescence in every
chapter house.
Fraternities might then
retain their dignity in the opening weeks of
the college year and might safely spare its the
evil of pledging in infancy.
Of course, the senior's responsibility in his
fraternity does not end with the freshman's
initiation, and it is fair to say that many older
fraternity men exercise a wholesome influence
over the rest of the chapter. Yet I believe
they could do much more. For example, in
at least one northern college it is no uncommon thing for a senior fraternity man to call
upon a freshman's adviser to ask about the
youngster's standing. In this way a student
whose head is in danger of being turned by
the new-found whirl of college pleasures may

THE NEWS-LETTER.

be saved a mistake he would regret. I have
known a fraternity man to make shipwreck of
his college course in the first few months,
when it semted to me that a good blowing-up
in the chapter house might have done more
for him than the admonitions of dean and
adviser together. I see no reason why the
seniors in a fraternity should not stand in loco
parentis even to a freshman who lives in Baltimore. They should see to it that he becomes
neither an over-conscientious grind nor an
unscrupulous loafer, that he does not thru
diffidence or indolence fail of his rightful
place in college affairs, and that he lacks no
praise or blame that a careful older brother
would not withhold.
Many freshmen do not, for a variety of
reasons become members of a fraternity.
They should not on that account be neglected.
I would have the Senior class president so far
presume upon his office as to see that no
freshman, by reason ot poverty or lack of
friends or for any cause except wilful indifference, should remain wholly out of the current of student activities. It follows that the
senior president should be chosen with care.
Obviously, he should be man of tried tact
with scholarship spfficient to assure him some
leisure for his task.
In conclusion, let me offer a specific suggestion. On account of the change to a
four-year course, the class of 1910 will have
at graduation scarcely more than a dozen or
fifteen members. In that year why not let the
Hullabaloo be issued jointly by 1910 and 1911
and thereafter by the Junior Class?
No
Hullabaloo comes off the press just when its
editors intend. The result is that the seniors
are burdened at the same time with their
final examinations, all the details of graduating exercises, and the business affairs of
an enterprise reaching nearly a thousand
dollars. Senior year should involve less
stress rather than more. It is the last opportunity before the engrossing specialization of
professional school or business for the following of culture courses, for some indulgence
of intellectual whim, and for such richer and
fuller college life as I think all alumni would
have Hopkins seniors enjoy and bequeath to
sophomores and freshmen.

THE CLASS RUSH.
The official opening of the University was
completed on Thursday, October the eighth,
when there took place the sophomore-freshman ''Rush." The occasion was perhaps
more in the nature of an afternoon tea than
in former years, as the ground was thickly
spread with tan-bark, this provision doing
away with much of the unpleasantness caused
by the filling of one's mouth with a superabundance of mother earth.
The rush itself was quite a successful affair,
particularly in the last two conflicts, when
the contestants appeared more warmed to the
work. The freshmen gathered at one end of
the arena and after the sophomores had given
a blood-curdling ''Hullabaloo," followed by a
shrill and defiant "Gee-bee, Gee-haa" from
the freshmen, signal was given, the two bands
rushed towards one another, and soon were
mingled in confusion. The sight of struggling
warriors, the waving arms and legs and the
cries of ''Rescue!" 'Freshman!" ''Sophie!"
were no less delightful to the handful of the
Faculty than to the older students who had
assembled as spectators at this feature of the
social activities of the University.
The "decision" was given to the freshmen
by the votes of the Officials and, in our
opinion, was really deserved. Both sides are
to be commended for the entire lack of bad
feeling, and the amount of ginger and energy
in the whole affair.
Finally, we wish to extend our sympathy
to a certain prominent professor of mathematics, who, by a miscalculation, arrived
just too late to view the conflict.

WALTER AND HAPPY RETURN.
Walter Noir, manufacturer of the famous
Hair Tonic, has returned to the University,
together with the no less popular — Happy."
Neither of these individuals appears to change
in the slightest from year to year and return
readier than ever to polish up our chins or
shoes, as the case may be. The welcome to
these two patriarchs of the University is so
uniVersal that it is scarcely necessary for us
to say that we rejoice at their coming.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE DEAL IN "J. & H."
Wall Street has had many leaders, but no
one-ever had it so completely under control as
Silas Bonds. No one has ever foretold so
accurately the actions of stocks, no one has
ever had so many blind followers, no one has
ever made so much money on the Exchange,
as Mr. Bonds. The reason for this can probably be found in the old adage "Nothing
succeeds like success," and everyone knows
that he has had but one failure and that even
this was not his fault. Several stories of why
the deal fell through are going the rounds,
but none are correct. Mr. Bonds is too
piqued and Harry Davis is too tickle to tell
the story in a form that will hand it down to
the brokers of future generations as it really
was, and so I, who am in a position to know,
feel that, as John Henry says, "it's up
tome."
One day last autumn, Mr. Bonds was at
his big mahogany desk, figuring out a deal in
"railways" by which he hoped to cripple his
already panic-wounded opponents so completely that he would have the floor to himself for some time. As he sat there, planning
carefully each move in the big deal, the card
of his wife's sister was brought in. Mr.
I3onds does not like to receive women in his
office, for he feels they have no business in
"The Street," but this lady's husband had
only recently died, naming him executor.
Accordingly, Mr. Bonds felt that he must
see her. When she was ushered in he met
her in the formally gracious way he uses towards all women, for hard, sharp business
man that he is, he has not forgotten what the
old school taught and expected.
"Oh! Silas," she said, gushingly, as is her
way, "I'm so sorry to trouble you, but really
I must see you on most important business.
You know poor Jack didn't leave nearly as
much as we thought he would and I've come
to ask if you can't tell me some stock I can
buy and sell in a day or two for more, so I
can buy more of those bonds you are going to
get for me."
"My dear Alice," replied Mr. Bonds,
smiling under his grey moustache and smoking
hard so that she would not see, "nothing is
sure in stocks and while I can probably find
you something compartively safe still I could

not guarantee that all your little fortune
might not be wiped out."
This frightened her and she said so, but he
hastened to reassure her by saying, "There
is little chance of losing all, but it is possible
that a small loss, which would mean a good
deal to you, might however be suffered. I
would advise you to risk, well say, only ten
thousand. I can buy you one hundred and
fifty shares of a security I have in mind,
using, of course, a small margin. The stock
is now selling at 81 and I am expecting it
to go to 150. I am buying all I can get myself. Are you willing to risk it?"
She was willing and so that morning the
house of Bonds & Company bought one hundred and fifty shares of Jerkwater and Huckleberry Railroad stock and entered it on the
books as the property of Mrs. Alice M.
Fowler. Each morning after, that lady, before she even looked at the weather, the day's
bargains, or the society news, opened her
Herald at the financial page and looked for
the cabalistic symbol `.J. & H.," and each
morning she found the figures opposite were
higher than the day before.
Silas Bonds had planned a deal in that
stock and the deal was working successfully.
First, he picked up all the floating shares he
could lay his hands on and then to inflate
its price, through his agents, his employees,
his friends, his allies, and perhaps, too, by
the aid of a little "washing." Slowly the
price rose, point by point, half point by half
point, till by Christmas it reached 1480.
Everything was ripe for the culmination of
the plan: a gradual unloading of the stock on
the market. This must be carefully done, for,
in spite of the apparent demand, it would be
a very easy thing to burst the bubble, since the
stock was quoting 'way above its true value.
No one had discovered the scheme. True,
Hogan & Company held a big block, but their
greed for the security would only catch them
the surer in the slump that eventually was
sure to come.
The day after Christmas, Mr. Bonds wrote
Mrs. Fowler, telling her that "J. & H.," in
his opinion, had reached the limit of its soar,
and asking her permission to sell her holdings.
That very evening Mrs. Fowler was seated at
dinner next to a Mr. Henry Davis, who, so

w5"

their hostess said, was "in Wall Street."
Accordingly, during a lull in the conversation,
the good lady told her dinner companion that
she was the proud possessor of one hundred
and fifty shares of "J. & H." Though "shop
talk" is not good "dinner talk," still Davis
could not resist the temptation of asking if she
would sell, as he was rather keen for J. & H."
"Oh! yes!" cried Mrs. Fowler, pleased
that this intelligent and apparently prosperous
young broker should take such a interest in
her dealing, and anxious to display her
knowledge of the market, "I'll sell for Silas—
I mean Mr. Silas Bonds, my brother-in-law.
He wrote me this morning that the stock had
gone as high as he could put it, and that he
was going to sell all he had."
Next morning "J. & H." broke with a
crash that could be heard from the Battery
to Harlem. In ten minutes it dropped from
14972 down to 91.Tg. The intelligent and
apparently prosperous young broker, who had
been Mrs. Fowler's confidant the evening before, was junior partner of Hogan & Company, and they, seeing a chance to pinch their
rivals hard, dumped all their "J. & H." on
the market.
There's a postscript to the story which Mr.
Bonds will not like me to tell, but it is surely
part of the history of the deal in "J. & H.
After the smoke of the first explosion settled
a bit, he sat down and drew a personal cheque
for twenty-two thousand four hundred and
five dollars in Mrs. Fowler's favor and sent it
to her, saying he had bought her stock at

songs. These were the excuses, "I don't
know the words," and 'I can't sing." Both
of these are absurd. The first is scarcely
legitimate, as the songs are printed in the
Hand-Book. The second is no excuse, for in
a crowd of students there must certainly be
one boy that can turn a tune, and if he starts,
the rest will follow.
Now, when Hopkins has such good songs,
it certainly seems deplorable that they are not
used. Think of the encouragement to the
teams! The players hear their classmates
urging them and naturally brace up. It may
seem odd to some that cheering can help a
team, but it is, nevertheless, true. Nearly
everyone has heard of the Princeton song,
"Old Nassau," and of the wonderful effect
the singing of this song has in arousing and
bracing up the teams. It is marvelous. The
Hopkins songs can be made to have the same
effect, if only they are sung. Therefore, this
fall, at the football games, let all the students
gather together and sing that inspiring song,
"Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land," the first
lines of which are:
"Come, stand together, we'll raise a cheer,
and wave the Black and Blue;

Tan-bark on the cage floor tastes better

'00.
John Philip Hill is running for Congress on
the Republican ticket.
T. Noel DeL. Purcell is travelling in
Italy.
'03.
R. S Lanier was married early in October.

B. G. Bird, ex-president of '09, is now
studying engineering at Wisconsin.

'06.
John A. Crane was married to Miss Mary
McKim on October 21st.

The new Handbook, commonly known as
the Freshmen's Bible, is even better than last
year's. Long life to it!

W. Conwell Smith and Reginald S. Opie,
'05, tied for first place in the '08 Law Class
at the University of Maryland, each winning
a hundred-dollar prize.

Some of us had the good fortune to see
Weems's mustache, which, however, disappeared soon after he reached the University,
but Sam Chew didn't have nerve enough to
show his mustache in this country.
A meeting of the Sophomore Class for the
election of officers was held Monday, October
12th. The following officers were elected:
President, Harry C. Burgan; Vice-President,
Raney Wolf; Secretary and Treasurer,
"Eddie" Hulbert; Historian, Herring; Sergeant-at-Arms, Wilson.

Mr. Nicholas Murray, who has been identified with Johns Hopkins University since
1879, holding successively the post s of
Assistant Librarian and Librarian, has tendered his resignation, a step which he has
had under consideration for a year or two
past. In addition to his duties as Librarian,
Mr. Murray has been manager of the Johns
Hopkins Press, which was organized under
his direction many years ago. He has rendered inestimable service to the University in
many ways and his resignation will be
accepted with regret. For the present Mr.
Murray will act in an advisory capacity only,
the active duties of the Librarian being temporarily assumed by Dr. M. L. Raney, the
present Assistant Librarian.

Carl Mengel, Carlyle Barton and W. Conwell Smith, all of whom graduated from the
University of Maryland Law School last
spring, have formed a partnership under the
head of Mengel, Barton and Smith.
Thomas G. Campbell, who has been
Assistant Head Master at St. James School,
Hagerstown, has returned to the University
as a medical student.

Miller and Roger Macaulay.
Julian W. Ridgely, ex-football captain, is

Master at the Boys' Country School, Baltimore.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

1:AMSNIg
It should not be a matter of surprise that
the daily newspapers all over the country hail
the opening of University, College and High
School alike, with full and detailed accounts
of athletic prospects, and with less notice of
the prospects of the schools as educational
institutions. It has been said that the papers
must keep their sporting .pages full, and that
the baseball season is just over; it has been
claimed that this is an age of athleticism run
wild; the real reason is, however, that school is
work and athletics is play. It goes without
saying that a more interesting and lively
newspaper story can be written about the
novelties of a college education than about its
realities, for it really is true that students
seem to pick up a football with more avidity
than they do books.
There is, however, a just complaint that is
made against too much newspaper talk about
the college athlete. I have heard it granted
readily that too much rushing into the public
eye usually achieves notoriety for a college
professor, but that the more a college athlete
gets his picture and his doughty deeds in
the paper, so much the more is his school
advertised, and his own fame increased.
Here, to my notion, lies the fallacy, and I
need only to cite the case of Ralph Rose to
make my point. The more advertising a man
gets, the more likely he is to think too well of
himself, and then he gets into trouble.
College athletics is a big topic and an absorbing one. About that there is no question.

But in the arguments about the autumn sport,
football, there are, now and then, things said
on both sides that are a bit unfair. For
instance, there is too much stress laid on the
accident side of football. Statistics show it to
be well down in the list of sports, when the
proportion is shown of participants and accidents. I was much struck with the detailed
statements which were given in a Pittsburg
paper four years ago. In a certain year, 1903
or 1904, there were more deaths in West
Virginia alone during the first week of the
hunting season than there had been in football in the whole of the United States in tell
years. And in comparison with automobile,
steamship and railroad accidents, football is,
as the boys say, "A squeak in a whirlwind."
Perhaps it is because the death or injury of a
fine, strong, young man, just at the beginning
of his career, seems so much more unnecessary
than the same thing in automobile or railroad
accidents.
Again, the blame for accidents is often put
where it does not belong. I remember the
sorrow in a certain Western college at the
death of a young man on the football team,
and also the bitterness of his family against
football. It developed very soon that the
young man had been doing, no matter what,
but several things that were contrary to the
training agreement under which the team had
voluntarily promised to work. When the big
scrimmage came, the young fellow was there
with all the will and pluck he had, but his

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

strength was undermined, and he went down.
That kind of a fellow might as well be killed
one way as another. A man will pay for dishonesty in athletics as well as anywhere else.
Football at Johns Hopkins seems to me to
be on a very sane basis, and for that reason
so much the more solid. On the agreement
that a student, who was not fit to represent
his university in scholastic lines, was not fit
to represent it in athletics, practically all the
schools in this country have the eligibility
rule based on class standing. The good faith
of one school or another has been called in
question, now and then, but to the honor of
Johns Hopkins be it said, that such has not
been the case here. The rule is right, no one
questions that. That it often works hardships on teams is certain. But I maintain
that this need not be true so often. Student
sentiment should and could compel the exact
compliance with both spirit and letter of the
law of training. But more, the class mates,
the fraternity brothers, or intimate friends,
should see to it that no man on any athletic
team is allowed to do poor work in his studies.
Whatever that man needs, help, encouragement, criticism, scorn, boycott, to stir up his
energies or arouse his sense of shame, that is
what he should get from the friends whom he,
as an athlete, is representing.
Johns Hopkins has reasons enough to feel
proud of its football team this year. There
is not as large a squad out as there should be,
but there is a fine spirit in the men who are
there. A good many of the necessary things
that go to make up a successful season are
ours. As good a field as any in the country,
a splendid grand-stand of concrete, a nucleus
of old men in the team, a good coach and a
tried one, harmony between the men and the
coach, a growing interest in the body of
alumni. Those are nearly enough to insure
success.
One thing more is absolutely necessary,
however, to make a football team. That is a
second team. It is the second team, the
scrubs, if you will, who are not good enough
to make the team this year, who may never be
good enough to make it, so far as that goes,
that makes the 'varsity team. I know men
who have played on the second team for four
years, and never made the "Team," but they

helped make it, and they knew it, and so did
everybody else, and the deserved credit came
their way. No team which plays only its
regular weekly games can hope to make a fair
showing against a team which has a daily
game, for, of course, that few minutes or half
hour of daily tussle with a second team accustoms the men to the chances and exigencies
of intercollegiate games.
If everybody who could get out and help,
would do so, would take his knocks, would
put up with the difficulties the manager often
has with clothes and shoes, would do his level
best, and not be too quick to think that he is
not being given a fair show, would live up
faithfully to the scholastic requirements he
knows to be just and right, Johns Hopkins
would not only have a successful team, and
one to be proud of, but it would feel the
increase of that kind of spirit which makes
Johns Hopkins known for its tenacity to
ideals, which aim at a just proportion for
every kind of university activity, and which
demand an honest, earnest and strenuous
endeavor in every one of them.
RALPH V. D. MAGOFFIN.

TRACK TEAM OUTLOOK.
The outlook for a winning track team this
year is certainly rosy, for there is more good
material in the University now than there has
been for a long time. Nearly all of the old
men are back again, and have already started
to limber up in the cage.
The Freshmen Class is especially rich in
athletic material, and will undoubtedly
strengthen the team considerably. One of
our weak spots last year, the broad jump, will
be capably filled by Martin, who did great
work for the City College last year. He is
also speedy in the hurdle and dash events.
Captain Brenton will be missed, but as Fulton,
also of the City College, has entered, he, with
"Old Reliable" Dutch Breyer, will make the
distance men sweat blood to win.
The dashes will be well taken care of, for
Jimmy Hunter, one of the best men on the
1906 team, has come back to help out. He,
with Captain Bailey, Stollenwerck and George
Stewart, will certainly form a speedy quartet.
Bridgman and Tappan, will be out again for
the hurdles; Maynard, Burgan and Tappan
for the high jump; and Stewart and Deming in
the broad. Bridgman will, as usual, take care
of the pole-vault. All of the old men in the
weights—Magoffin, Miller and Bryant—will
be back.
The schedule of games has not been arranged as yet, but we will have dual meets
with Virginia, the Navy, Dickinson, Haverford and, perhaps, Swarthmore. Besides the
dual meets, there will be two open meets—
one in the cage or armory and one at Homewood.
Above all, we must have a winning relay
team this year. If all the men who can run
will come out and work, there is not a reason
in the world why we should not have a winner. All of the places are open, and everybody will be given a fair chance. If you can
run, or even if you think you might be able to

run, respond to the first call for practise, and
come out and work. Let's have a team that
will beat everything we run against this year.
LACROSSE 1909.
We are going to have a championship
lacrosse team this year. That is almost an
undisputable fact, for last year we had a
championship team and this year we will have
all our old men except three—Walter Blanck,
Charlie Myers and Ralph Williams.
From this fact, however, it does not result
that the squad should be small this year. We
want a big lacrosse squad this year, in fact
we must have it if we expect to uphold our
reputation in the next few years to come. It
is true that there will be few places open on
the team, but there will be an entirely different story in 1910, for then almost all of our
present playing strength will have completed
their four years.
Now, everybody knows that first-class
lacrosse men are not developed in one year or
even two. The more the experience, the
better the player. This fact was conelusively
proved in the game with Toronto last season.
In 1910 and 1911 the entire burden of putting
out a championship team will fall on the
shoulders of the present Freshmen and Sophomores. Therefore, it is more necessary than
ever before that a large squad come out and
get us their stickwork.
Stickwork, however, is not the only thing
that is necessary to develop a championship
squad. Endurance is a most important factor,
and it is to develop this that the cross country
runs are being held twice every week. Look
on the bulletin board and see when the next
is to be held and then go out and run.

THE RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS FOR 1910.
The next Qualifying Examination for Scholars in the United States under the Rhodes
Bequest will be held in October 1909; the
selection will be made before the end of
January 1910, and the elected Scholars will
begin residence at Oxford in October of the
same year.
Inquiries respecting the Scholarships for
Maryland may be addressed to President
Remsen, Johns Hopkins University, who is
chairman of the Committee for Maryland.

The new laboratory for Plant Physiology, a photograph of which we
publish on this page, is now completed. It is situated, with the adjacent
botanical gardens, just north of the Wyman mansion and west of the Carroll
mansion (Country School). It is directly behind the site of the proposed chapel.
It will be used by the graduate students of botany, under the direction of
Associate Professor Duncan Johnson. The well-equipped greenhouse which
adjoins it, is to be used for the cultivation of delicate plants. About 300
species are now set out and growing.
As the photograph indicates, the building is small, but it is of attractive
design, which will not jar with the magnificent structures which will in time
surround it.

NCE more the University has opened its doors to its students, and
college activities have begun with a vim. In this first issue of the
NEWS-LETTER the Board of Editors takes the opportunity to welcome
all the old students back as well as the Freshmen. It is not necessary to give another account of the policy of the paper, for this was
printed in one of the issues of last spring.
However, one change will be made, and that is to publish instead of a story in each number, an article written by one of the
faculty on whatever subject the author may select. For the first of
this series of leading articles we are greatly indebted to Dr. French,
who has written thoughtfully upon a very vital question, in which the undergraduates
especially will be interested.
We expect to have many other articles which will be just as important and delightful
to read. These articles if nothing more should make the students take a renewed interest in
the NEWS-LETTER. We shall also have a new cover design for each issue. These designs
will be the product of the students, and we shall be glad to receive for the approval of the
Board original pictures from all who draw. These will make the paper as attractive on the
outside as it will be on the inside.

Mr. J. Purdon Wright, who put the NEWS-LETTER on its present good financial basis,
has resigned, greatly to the regret of the board. We take pleasure in announcing the election
of Mr. H. P. Makel to succeed Mr. Wright as Business Manager.

A friend of the University has presented to it a collection of coins formed between 1850
and 1880 by the Marquis de Molius, a Spanish diplomatist, who served as Ambassador in
Paris and London. After his death it passed into the hands of Don Antonio Vives, the wellknown collector and numismatist of Madrid, from whom it was recently purchased. The
collection comprises more than 3,000 specimens, and includes coins of the Roman Republic,
(gold, silver and copper), of the Roman Emperors, (gold, 44, silver and copper), and 837
coins of the Iberian and Roman-Spanish cities and colonies issued prior to the reign of Caligula.
In this series of early Spanish coins lies the chief value of the collection, many of the known
issues represented being excessively rare, and several specimens in this collection being, so far
as is known, unique. Many years would be required to form another such Spanish collection,
and it would be most difficult to secure so many well-preserved specimens. The main interest
of this primitive Spanish coinage lies in the fact that it represents early Iberian art, and that it
furnishes the best original material for the solution of the many problems connected with the
Iberian language and Iberian epigraphy.
Don Antonio Vives, the last owner of the collection, by whom it was, to some extent,
enlarged, is author of the standard work on the coinage of the Spanish Moors, "Monedas de
las Dinastias Arabigo-Espanolas," Madrid, 1893. He formed the collection of Hispano_
Moorish coins now in the National Archological Museum at Madrid, which the Spanish
Government bought from him for 110,000 pesetas, and he owns the best private collection of
primitive Iberian bronzes, to which reference is made in many publications on this subject.
The following gifts have also been received recently for the department of Botany:
From the Park Commissioners of Baltimore, through Superintendent Manning, cuttings
of 50 species of exotic plants and 10 young plants; from Mrs. Augustus Hoen, of Baltimore, a
splendid specimen of Cycas revoluta and a fine clump of Strelitzia regince; from Professor H. S.
Collard, of Iowa College, formerly a Johnston Scholar of the University, a 1,000-gram chemical
balance.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

UPPER CLASSMEN AND LOWER.
BY JOHN C. FRENCH.

Being an upper-classman at Hopkins may,
perhaps, be regarded as a greater honor now
than in former years. The present seniors,
tho themselves completing a three-year course,
are as a class the last who will do so. From
now on seniors, being separated from freshmen by a greater interval, may justly demand
the greater respect from them, and in the
traditional enmity between sophomores and
freshmen, never having been the rivals of
either, they may now hold an unembarrassed
neutrality. Advice to new students as to
their part in college life has never been
scanty; they get kindly, wholesome words
from the Dean at matriculation, exhortations
from the captains of teams and clubs at the
opening reception, and fatherly counsel in
private from their advisers. Of such official
patronizing they have perhaps enough. The
time is opportune, however, to ask that upperclassmen shall take stock of their opportunities
and look their responsibilities in the face.
Those alumni who are concerned that
student life at Hopkins shall be enriched
with worthy traditions—and no others—look
to the upper-classmen to inaugurate and maintain them. Tho speaking as one having no
authority, I venture to say that both faculty
and alumni would give their moral support to
a greater dominance over college customs by
seniors. Let me hazard a few suggestions as
to what they would have seniors do.
Without question, the alumni would have
seniors put away childish things. Otherwise
they can serve no useful purpose as arbiters of
college affairs. A certain regrettable incident
of last year's student frivolity was all the
more regrettable because the disturbance—itself without precedent or excuse—was incited
and abetted by seniors.
Again, they would have seniors free themselves from all manner of partiality. As between freshmen and sophomores, they must be
capable of a judicial attitude. Students expect, and rightly, that such members of the
faculty as belong to fraternities having chapters here shall not carry the least memory of
their affiliations into the class room. An
equal impartiality should be possible to seniors.
The censor of college customs must wield a
spear that knows no brother.

If there is to be hazing—and I beg leave to
evade altogether the question whether there
should be—we should welcome some guarantee
that it wiil not be carried beyond the limits of
good-natured buffoonery. Is it not possible
to establish a tradition that no hazing whatever shall go on without the presence of a
Senior whose veto would be instantly respected? A referee is thought necessary when
the parties to a sport are evenly matched.
How much more necessary when one of them
is overborne by numbers and is expected for
the sake of future college spirit to carry away
no rancor in his heart! . I believe there has
been no brutal hazing at Johns Hopkins; yet
there have been freshmen, disposed to take
their hazing impersonally and as a sort of
initiation to Hopkins life, who have carried
on in bitterness the conviction that in their
case the limits of reasonable exaction had
been over-stepped. It is to prevent this, as
well as the possibility, remote as it is here,
perhaps, of physical injury thru some sophomore's excessive zeal, that I would have no
hazing except under rigid senior control.
Where there are several fraternities and
none too many students, rivalry becomes
keen and abuses are likely to creep in. It is
no secret that at Hopkins some regulation of
inter-fraternity competition is needed. To the
upper-classmen, again, we look for the inauguration of reforms. This may not be a matter
for legislation by the senior class-meeting, but
a senior pan-hellenic conference might reach
conclusions to which the weight of their influence would secure acquiescence in every
chapter house.
Fraternities might then
retain their dignity in the opening weeks of
the college year and might safely spare its the
evil of pledging in infancy.
Of course, the senior's responsibility in his
fraternity does not end with the freshman's
initiation, and it is fair to say that many older
fraternity men exercise a wholesome influence
over the rest of the chapter. Yet I believe
they could do much more. For example, in
at least one northern college it is no uncommon thing for a senior fraternity man to call
upon a freshman's adviser to ask about the
youngster's standing. In this way a student
whose head is in danger of being turned by
the new-found whirl of college pleasures may

THE NEWS-LETTER.

be saved a mistake he would regret. I have
known a fraternity man to make shipwreck of
his college course in the first few months,
when it semted to me that a good blowing-up
in the chapter house might have done more
for him than the admonitions of dean and
adviser together. I see no reason why the
seniors in a fraternity should not stand in loco
parentis even to a freshman who lives in Baltimore. They should see to it that he becomes
neither an over-conscientious grind nor an
unscrupulous loafer, that he does not thru
diffidence or indolence fail of his rightful
place in college affairs, and that he lacks no
praise or blame that a careful older brother
would not withhold.
Many freshmen do not, for a variety of
reasons become members of a fraternity.
They should not on that account be neglected.
I would have the Senior class president so far
presume upon his office as to see that no
freshman, by reason ot poverty or lack of
friends or for any cause except wilful indifference, should remain wholly out of the current of student activities. It follows that the
senior president should be chosen with care.
Obviously, he should be man of tried tact
with scholarship spfficient to assure him some
leisure for his task.
In conclusion, let me offer a specific suggestion. On account of the change to a
four-year course, the class of 1910 will have
at graduation scarcely more than a dozen or
fifteen members. In that year why not let the
Hullabaloo be issued jointly by 1910 and 1911
and thereafter by the Junior Class?
No
Hullabaloo comes off the press just when its
editors intend. The result is that the seniors
are burdened at the same time with their
final examinations, all the details of graduating exercises, and the business affairs of
an enterprise reaching nearly a thousand
dollars. Senior year should involve less
stress rather than more. It is the last opportunity before the engrossing specialization of
professional school or business for the following of culture courses, for some indulgence
of intellectual whim, and for such richer and
fuller college life as I think all alumni would
have Hopkins seniors enjoy and bequeath to
sophomores and freshmen.

THE CLASS RUSH.
The official opening of the University was
completed on Thursday, October the eighth,
when there took place the sophomore-freshman ''Rush." The occasion was perhaps
more in the nature of an afternoon tea than
in former years, as the ground was thickly
spread with tan-bark, this provision doing
away with much of the unpleasantness caused
by the filling of one's mouth with a superabundance of mother earth.
The rush itself was quite a successful affair,
particularly in the last two conflicts, when
the contestants appeared more warmed to the
work. The freshmen gathered at one end of
the arena and after the sophomores had given
a blood-curdling ''Hullabaloo," followed by a
shrill and defiant "Gee-bee, Gee-haa" from
the freshmen, signal was given, the two bands
rushed towards one another, and soon were
mingled in confusion. The sight of struggling
warriors, the waving arms and legs and the
cries of ''Rescue!" 'Freshman!" ''Sophie!"
were no less delightful to the handful of the
Faculty than to the older students who had
assembled as spectators at this feature of the
social activities of the University.
The "decision" was given to the freshmen
by the votes of the Officials and, in our
opinion, was really deserved. Both sides are
to be commended for the entire lack of bad
feeling, and the amount of ginger and energy
in the whole affair.
Finally, we wish to extend our sympathy
to a certain prominent professor of mathematics, who, by a miscalculation, arrived
just too late to view the conflict.

WALTER AND HAPPY RETURN.
Walter Noir, manufacturer of the famous
Hair Tonic, has returned to the University,
together with the no less popular — Happy."
Neither of these individuals appears to change
in the slightest from year to year and return
readier than ever to polish up our chins or
shoes, as the case may be. The welcome to
these two patriarchs of the University is so
uniVersal that it is scarcely necessary for us
to say that we rejoice at their coming.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE DEAL IN "J. & H."
Wall Street has had many leaders, but no
one-ever had it so completely under control as
Silas Bonds. No one has ever foretold so
accurately the actions of stocks, no one has
ever had so many blind followers, no one has
ever made so much money on the Exchange,
as Mr. Bonds. The reason for this can probably be found in the old adage "Nothing
succeeds like success," and everyone knows
that he has had but one failure and that even
this was not his fault. Several stories of why
the deal fell through are going the rounds,
but none are correct. Mr. Bonds is too
piqued and Harry Davis is too tickle to tell
the story in a form that will hand it down to
the brokers of future generations as it really
was, and so I, who am in a position to know,
feel that, as John Henry says, "it's up
tome."
One day last autumn, Mr. Bonds was at
his big mahogany desk, figuring out a deal in
"railways" by which he hoped to cripple his
already panic-wounded opponents so completely that he would have the floor to himself for some time. As he sat there, planning
carefully each move in the big deal, the card
of his wife's sister was brought in. Mr.
I3onds does not like to receive women in his
office, for he feels they have no business in
"The Street," but this lady's husband had
only recently died, naming him executor.
Accordingly, Mr. Bonds felt that he must
see her. When she was ushered in he met
her in the formally gracious way he uses towards all women, for hard, sharp business
man that he is, he has not forgotten what the
old school taught and expected.
"Oh! Silas," she said, gushingly, as is her
way, "I'm so sorry to trouble you, but really
I must see you on most important business.
You know poor Jack didn't leave nearly as
much as we thought he would and I've come
to ask if you can't tell me some stock I can
buy and sell in a day or two for more, so I
can buy more of those bonds you are going to
get for me."
"My dear Alice," replied Mr. Bonds,
smiling under his grey moustache and smoking
hard so that she would not see, "nothing is
sure in stocks and while I can probably find
you something compartively safe still I could

not guarantee that all your little fortune
might not be wiped out."
This frightened her and she said so, but he
hastened to reassure her by saying, "There
is little chance of losing all, but it is possible
that a small loss, which would mean a good
deal to you, might however be suffered. I
would advise you to risk, well say, only ten
thousand. I can buy you one hundred and
fifty shares of a security I have in mind,
using, of course, a small margin. The stock
is now selling at 81 and I am expecting it
to go to 150. I am buying all I can get myself. Are you willing to risk it?"
She was willing and so that morning the
house of Bonds & Company bought one hundred and fifty shares of Jerkwater and Huckleberry Railroad stock and entered it on the
books as the property of Mrs. Alice M.
Fowler. Each morning after, that lady, before she even looked at the weather, the day's
bargains, or the society news, opened her
Herald at the financial page and looked for
the cabalistic symbol `.J. & H.," and each
morning she found the figures opposite were
higher than the day before.
Silas Bonds had planned a deal in that
stock and the deal was working successfully.
First, he picked up all the floating shares he
could lay his hands on and then to inflate
its price, through his agents, his employees,
his friends, his allies, and perhaps, too, by
the aid of a little "washing." Slowly the
price rose, point by point, half point by half
point, till by Christmas it reached 1480.
Everything was ripe for the culmination of
the plan: a gradual unloading of the stock on
the market. This must be carefully done, for,
in spite of the apparent demand, it would be
a very easy thing to burst the bubble, since the
stock was quoting 'way above its true value.
No one had discovered the scheme. True,
Hogan & Company held a big block, but their
greed for the security would only catch them
the surer in the slump that eventually was
sure to come.
The day after Christmas, Mr. Bonds wrote
Mrs. Fowler, telling her that "J. & H.," in
his opinion, had reached the limit of its soar,
and asking her permission to sell her holdings.
That very evening Mrs. Fowler was seated at
dinner next to a Mr. Henry Davis, who, so

It should not be a matter of surprise that
the daily newspapers all over the country hail
the opening of University, College and High
School alike, with full and detailed accounts
of athletic prospects, and with less notice of
the prospects of the schools as educational
institutions. It has been said that the papers
must keep their sporting .pages full, and that
the baseball season is just over; it has been
claimed that this is an age of athleticism run
wild; the real reason is, however, that school is
work and athletics is play. It goes without
saying that a more interesting and lively
newspaper story can be written about the
novelties of a college education than about its
realities, for it really is true that students
seem to pick up a football with more avidity
than they do books.
There is, however, a just complaint that is
made against too much newspaper talk about
the college athlete. I have heard it granted
readily that too much rushing into the public
eye usually achieves notoriety for a college
professor, but that the more a college athlete
gets his picture and his doughty deeds in
the paper, so much the more is his school
advertised, and his own fame increased.
Here, to my notion, lies the fallacy, and I
need only to cite the case of Ralph Rose to
make my point. The more advertising a man
gets, the more likely he is to think too well of
himself, and then he gets into trouble.
College athletics is a big topic and an absorbing one. About that there is no question.

But in the arguments about the autumn sport,
football, there are, now and then, things said
on both sides that are a bit unfair. For
instance, there is too much stress laid on the
accident side of football. Statistics show it to
be well down in the list of sports, when the
proportion is shown of participants and accidents. I was much struck with the detailed
statements which were given in a Pittsburg
paper four years ago. In a certain year, 1903
or 1904, there were more deaths in West
Virginia alone during the first week of the
hunting season than there had been in football in the whole of the United States in tell
years. And in comparison with automobile,
steamship and railroad accidents, football is,
as the boys say, "A squeak in a whirlwind."
Perhaps it is because the death or injury of a
fine, strong, young man, just at the beginning
of his career, seems so much more unnecessary
than the same thing in automobile or railroad
accidents.
Again, the blame for accidents is often put
where it does not belong. I remember the
sorrow in a certain Western college at the
death of a young man on the football team,
and also the bitterness of his family against
football. It developed very soon that the
young man had been doing, no matter what,
but several things that were contrary to the
training agreement under which the team had
voluntarily promised to work. When the big
scrimmage came, the young fellow was there
with all the will and pluck he had, but his

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

strength was undermined, and he went down.
That kind of a fellow might as well be killed
one way as another. A man will pay for dishonesty in athletics as well as anywhere else.
Football at Johns Hopkins seems to me to
be on a very sane basis, and for that reason
so much the more solid. On the agreement
that a student, who was not fit to represent
his university in scholastic lines, was not fit
to represent it in athletics, practically all the
schools in this country have the eligibility
rule based on class standing. The good faith
of one school or another has been called in
question, now and then, but to the honor of
Johns Hopkins be it said, that such has not
been the case here. The rule is right, no one
questions that. That it often works hardships on teams is certain. But I maintain
that this need not be true so often. Student
sentiment should and could compel the exact
compliance with both spirit and letter of the
law of training. But more, the class mates,
the fraternity brothers, or intimate friends,
should see to it that no man on any athletic
team is allowed to do poor work in his studies.
Whatever that man needs, help, encouragement, criticism, scorn, boycott, to stir up his
energies or arouse his sense of shame, that is
what he should get from the friends whom he,
as an athlete, is representing.
Johns Hopkins has reasons enough to feel
proud of its football team this year. There
is not as large a squad out as there should be,
but there is a fine spirit in the men who are
there. A good many of the necessary things
that go to make up a successful season are
ours. As good a field as any in the country,
a splendid grand-stand of concrete, a nucleus
of old men in the team, a good coach and a
tried one, harmony between the men and the
coach, a growing interest in the body of
alumni. Those are nearly enough to insure
success.
One thing more is absolutely necessary,
however, to make a football team. That is a
second team. It is the second team, the
scrubs, if you will, who are not good enough
to make the team this year, who may never be
good enough to make it, so far as that goes,
that makes the 'varsity team. I know men
who have played on the second team for four
years, and never made the "Team," but they

helped make it, and they knew it, and so did
everybody else, and the deserved credit came
their way. No team which plays only its
regular weekly games can hope to make a fair
showing against a team which has a daily
game, for, of course, that few minutes or half
hour of daily tussle with a second team accustoms the men to the chances and exigencies
of intercollegiate games.
If everybody who could get out and help,
would do so, would take his knocks, would
put up with the difficulties the manager often
has with clothes and shoes, would do his level
best, and not be too quick to think that he is
not being given a fair show, would live up
faithfully to the scholastic requirements he
knows to be just and right, Johns Hopkins
would not only have a successful team, and
one to be proud of, but it would feel the
increase of that kind of spirit which makes
Johns Hopkins known for its tenacity to
ideals, which aim at a just proportion for
every kind of university activity, and which
demand an honest, earnest and strenuous
endeavor in every one of them.
RALPH V. D. MAGOFFIN.

STEVENS NEXT.
Our fellows will back up against a tough
proposition when they play Stevens next
Saturday, for the Hoboken team has certainly been playing great football up to the
present time. It has already played five
hard games and in the last two contests its
form has been greatly improved. Although
outweighed by fifteen pounds it played the
strong Union eleven to a standstill, Lehigh
which always has a strong eleven, was only
able to score one touchdown against the Stute
team. In the third game, which was with
Princeton, Stevens played so strongly that
the Tigers scored only four touchdowns in

TRACK TEAM OUTLOOK.
The outlook for a winning track team this
year is certainly rosy, for there is more good
material in the University now than there has
been for a long time. Nearly all of the old
men are back again, and have already started
to limber up in the cage.
The Freshmen Class is especially rich in
athletic material, and will undoubtedly
strengthen the team considerably. One of
our weak spots last year, the broad jump, will
be capably filled by Martin, who did great
work for the City College last year. He is
also speedy in the hurdle and dash events.
Captain Brenton will be missed, but as Fulton,
also of the City College, has entered, he, with
"Old Reliable" Dutch Breyer, will make the
distance men sweat blood to win.
The dashes will be well taken care of, for
Jimmy Hunter, one of the best men on the
1906 team, has come back to help out. He,
with Captain Bailey, Stollenwerck and George
Stewart, will certainly form a speedy quartet.
Bridgman and Tappan, will be out again for
the hurdles; Maynard, Burgan and Tappan
for the high jump; and Stewart and Deming in
the broad. Bridgman will, as usual, take care
of the pole-vault. All of the old men in the
weights—Magoffin, Miller and Bryant—will
be back.
The schedule of games has not been arranged as yet, but we will have dual meets
with Virginia, the Navy, Dickinson, Haverford and, perhaps, Swarthmore. Besides the
dual meets, there will be two open meets—
one in the cage or armory and one at Homewood.
Above all, we must have a winning relay
team this year. If all the men who can run
will come out and work, there is not a reason
in the world why we should not have a winner. All of the places are open, and everybody will be given a fair chance. If you can
run, or even if you think you might be able to

run, respond to the first call for practise, and
come out and work. Let's have a team that
will beat everything we run against this year.
LACROSSE 1909.
We are going to have a championship
lacrosse team this year. That is almost an
undisputable fact, for last year we had a
championship team and this year we will have
all our old men except three—Walter Blanck,
Charlie Myers and Ralph Williams.
From this fact, however, it does not result
that the squad should be small this year. We
want a big lacrosse squad this year, in fact
we must have it if we expect to uphold our
reputation in the next few years to come. It
is true that there will be few places open on
the team, but there will be an entirely different story in 1910, for then almost all of our
present playing strength will have completed
their four years.
Now, everybody knows that first-class
lacrosse men are not developed in one year or
even two. The more the experience, the
better the player. This fact was conelusively
proved in the game with Toronto last season.
In 1910 and 1911 the entire burden of putting
out a championship team will fall on the
shoulders of the present Freshmen and Sophomores. Therefore, it is more necessary than
ever before that a large squad come out and
get us their stickwork.
Stickwork, however, is not the only thing
that is necessary to develop a championship
squad. Endurance is a most important factor,
and it is to develop this that the cross country
runs are being held twice every week. Look
on the bulletin board and see when the next
is to be held and then go out and run.

THE RHODES SCHOLARSHIPS FOR 1910.
The next Qualifying Examination for Scholars in the United States under the Rhodes
Bequest will be held in October 1909; the
selection will be made before the end of
January 1910, and the elected Scholars will
begin residence at Oxford in October of the
same year.
Inquiries respecting the Scholarships for
Maryland may be addressed to President
Remsen, Johns Hopkins University, who is
chairman of the Committee for Maryland.
